# Notes for c4ptur3-th3-fl4g

## Questions
---

### Part 1

```c4n y0u c4p7u23 7h3 f149?```

"can you capture the flag"

```
01101100 01100101 01110100 01110011 00100000 01110100 01110010 01111001 00100000 01110011 01101111 01101101 01100101 00100000 01100010 01101001 01101110 01100001 01110010 01111001 00100000 01101111 01110101 01110100 00100001
```

Binary to ascii conversion: "lets try some binary out!"

```
MJQXGZJTGIQGS4ZAON2XAZLSEBRW63LNN5XCA2LOEBBVIRRHOM======
```
base32 to ascii: "base32 is super common in CTF's"

```
RWFjaCBCYXNlNjQgZGlnaXQgcmVwcmVzZW50cyBleGFjdGx5IDYgYml0cyBvZiBkYXRhLg==
```
base64 to ascii: "Each Base64 digit represents exactly 6 bits of data."
```
68 65 78 61 64 65 63 69 6d 61 6c 20 6f 72 20 62 61 73 65 31 36 3f
```
hexadecimal to ascii: "hexadecimal or base16?"
```
Ebgngr zr 13 cynprf!
```
rot13: "Rotate me 13 places!"
```
*@F DA:? >6 C:89E C@F?5 323J C:89E C@F?5 Wcf E:>6DX
```
rot47: "You spin me right round baby right round (47 times)"
```
- . .-.. . -.-. --- -- -- ..- -. .. -.-. .- - .. --- -.
. -. -.-. --- -.. .. -. --.
```
morse code to ascii: "telecommunication encoding"
```
85 110 112 97 99 107 32 116 104 105 115 32 66 67 68
```

There wasn't a nice online tool for this that gave me the correct results, so instead I used a quick python script I made

```python
"".join([chr(int(l)) for l in "< input >".split()])
```
ascii numbers to ascii: "Unpack this BCD"

```

```
* LS0= decode to morse
* morse to binary
* binary to ascii
* rot47
* ascii number to ascii: "Let's make this a bit trickier..."
